subject: Re: [Fwd: Re: Re: [Read_Alphabet] [Fwd: Ever-circular - traveling handwritten letters]]
msgSnippet: I think creating a new group isn t a bad idea. It d keep everything cleanly separated: Read_Alphabet for general talk, Read_Alphabet_Letters (or whatever) for
messageBody:
I think creating a new group isn't a bad idea.
It'd keep everything cleanly separated: Read_Alphabet for general talk,
Read_Alphabet_Letters (or whatever) for posting letter scans.
Plus we'd get another 100mb .

Personally I'd advocate a naming convention for scans, say the date,
followed by an username, followed by the page number.
So you might have "2007-09-22-amd64_hacker-01.jpg" for example.
That would keep everything effortlessly in order, if you have anything
more to say about the scan you can say it in the description field.

I think that there should be a time limit on how fast letters can be
written and an order for people to reply in.
One of the things about a letter is that it takes time (days, sometimes
weeks) to be delivered.
That means that authors can and often do spend an extra ten minutes
considering the letter, their word choices and their hand writing.

The trouble with being able to reply to anyone instantly is that if you
begin to feel guilty if you don't.

Really what I'm saying is that we want the advantages (reliability and
speed) of instant communication with out the disadvantages (messages are
short, fragmented, quickly written and digital) of instant communication.

Anyway I think order/rota and time limit would help keep the letter-esq
qualities, but I may be over analysing this - I do that sometimes.

Paige Gabhart wrote:
>
>
>
> -------- Original Message --------
> Subject: Re: [Norton AntiSpam] Re: [Read_Alphabet] [Fwd:
> Ever-circular - traveling handwritten letters]
> Date: Sat, 22 Sep 2007 17:13:12 -0400
> From: Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...>
> To: Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com
> References: <46F56BF6.50309@...>
> <35d570de0709221309h6a062249n41c8440b164f5d22@...>
>
>
>
> Benjamin:
>
> I have sent a trial pdf letter to amd64_hacker which I saved as a 1
> bit pdf. This 2 page letter only took up 60kb. If I save it as JPEG,
> I believe the file would be approximately 10 times that size. I am
> waiting to see if the copy amd64_hacker received seems good enough to
> use. The resolution may be a little too thin -- at least for the pen
> I used.
>
> The pdf format lets us make a multi-page file if we want to, and it
> really isn't that much additional trouble. You make your individual
> scans, then use PDF.995 to combine them into a single file. So the
> process would be something like this: a person downloads an existing
> file from the website, scans his letter, saves it as a pdf file. Uses
> PDF.995 to combine his addition to the existing file and then uploads
> the whole shebang back to the website replacing the original file.
>
> Regarding JPEG: is there any way that a second writer can append a
> scan of their QS addition to an original JPEG scan? If not, then we
> would just be uploading a series of disconnected letters (files) to
> the site and it would not be obvious who was responding to what.
> Perhaps that doesn't matter, but it would be different from the
> original concept of a letter that makes the rounds and is added to by
> each new reader. The latter idea would seem to encourage people to
> participate. We could have uploaded scanned writing seven years ago
> when I started the website, but that has not happened to any great extent.
>
> I can start another site for reading (and the encouragement of
> writing) practice. That would give us another 100mb of space devoted
> to that purpose if that is the consensus of the people interested in this.
>
>
> Paige
>
> Benjamin Bruce wrote:
>
>> Those who don't have the software to make PDF's (or those who
>> don't want to bother figuring out how) could just save their scans as
>> JPEG, as long as they weren't too gigantic. In this case, a PDF
>> would practically serve as another picture format, since it will be
>> handwritten text. My suggestion would be to make a separate e-mail
>> group for those who want to participate, so we wouldn't have to keep
>> track of everyone who's on the list.
>> Sign me up, by the way--if anyone needs practice reading
>> Quickscript, it's me!
>>
>> -Benjamin Bruce
>>
>> 2007/9/22, Paige Gabhart < pgabhart@...
>> <mailto:pgabhart@...>>:
>>
>> didn't go through the first time.
>>
>> -------- Original Message --------
>> Subject: Ever-circular - traveling handwritten letters
>> Date: Sat, 22 Sep 2007 15:16:43 -0400
>> From: Paige Gabhart <pgabhart@...>
>> <mailto:pgabhart@...>
>> To: Read_alphabet@yahoogroups.com
>> <mailto:Read_alphabet@yahoogroups.com>
>>
>>
>>
>> I started out this morning thinking about the idea of a handwritten text
>> in QS for group members who are interested to participate in. It looked
>> as if Google docs had such a service permitting documents to be uploaded
>>
>> and then viewed by members approved to see them. I thought that pdf
>> would be an effective way to upload these scanned handwritten letters so
>> I checked the googel docs site, and it stated that pdf was one of the
>>
>> formats they use. So I then handwrote a letter, which was two pages
>> long, scanned it, saved it in pdf form, put it through PDF.995, which is
>> a free program which combined the two pages into a single document, and
>>
>> then went to google docs, registered and attempted to upload the pdf
>> file. It was at this point after going to their user forums that I
>> discovered that you can only _download_ pdf files, not _upload_ them. I
>>
>> love sites that don't make it clear what their restrictions are!
>>
>> We could upload these letters to the group site, but how do we control
>> who adds to them and when or does it make a difference. Also,
>>
>> Yahoogroups limits our files saved on their server to 100mb. We could
>> just send the pdf file as an attachment in an e-mail to the people
>> interested in the reading practice. If we had a list of the people
>> interested, I could send my letter to the first person on the list, who
>>
>> then adds their letter to it (again, using PDF.995 to combine the pdf
>> files), and forwards it to the next person on the list.
>>
>> Is there another format that would be more compact than pdf and/or work
>> better for what we are trying to accomplish?
>>
>>
>> Any comments, ideas, suggestions?
>>
>> Paige
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>>
>> --
>> Check out Ziphen Central!
>> Weekly posts on interesting and unique topics.
>> http://ziphen.benjaminbruce.com <http://ziphen.benjaminbruce.com>
>
>

Subject: Re: [Fwd: Re: Re: [Read_Alphabet] [Fwd: Ever-circular - traveling
 handwritten letters]]
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=180175951; y=RHR3RtmUOLDe-AyyHtTNAvziyzNfenyayFajEi-tyDRLFhDgnzS5
X-Yahoo-Profile: amd64_hacker
